posts.name: Yazwq
posts.cooked: I think wcp swerve x2 for price. What is your opinion?

posts.name: Michael Havrylyuk
posts.cooked: We have been super happy with MaxSwerve. The new spikey wheels are super nice and last much longer than we expected. The reality is most teams will not be able to tell the difference between the modules and should focus on how they integrate with the rest of the robot (size, encoder compatibility, etc).

posts.name: Kyle Swaidner
posts.cooked: We had Max swerve last year and switched to WCP X2 this season.  I think everyone on the team would say it was a significant upgrade.  Ease of assembly and maintenance are better, reliability is better (no ultraplanetaries, no odd motor keys, no separate motor controllers with non-latching and easily damaged connectors), and both grip and tread life are much better.  The only thing we lost is some arrangement volume and weight.  I don’t have a single bad thing to say about the X2 modules.

posts.name: John Bottenberg
posts.cooked: Haven’t done anything besides SDS MK4i. For those who switched away from SDS , why did you do it? Knowing what you know now, was it a good idea to switch?

3384a6f4cb0be7ea28272ff7cf8d1f4f.name: I ask a whole lot of questions

posts.name: Yazwq
posts.cooked: What do you think about the new models of wcp?

posts.name: Esat
posts.cooked: @Andrew_L help dude!

posts.name: joemost
posts.cooked:
John_Bottenberg:

Haven’t done anything besides SDS MK4i. For those who switched away from SDS , why did you do it? Knowing what you know now, was it a good idea to switch?

Yeah this is where we are at. I’d speculate given the cost and how new swerve is, most teams will have just used one module version.

We bought MK4i’s in 2023. Then another set in 2024. and then another set in 2025.

We’ve literally never had a failure with them. Only thing we’ve ever changed is the gearing.  Have just never had a reason to look elsewhere. And now there is incentive to just stay on one system anyways

posts.name: Andrew Lawrence
posts.cooked: I believe in you

posts.name: Andrew Todd
posts.cooked:
Our team uses SDS MK4i modules with CTRE Cancoders, a CTRE pigeon 2.0, and Kraken X60 motors.

The Krakens were new to us this season and they’re soooo good. Huge improvement over the Neos we used last season.

posts.name: Andrew Todd
posts.cooked: In our case, SDS is based very close by too. Shipping time is basically non-existent.

posts.name: Esat
posts.cooked: x2 or x2s which one bro? what do u think?

posts.name: Hefti
posts.cooked: I think that the drivetrain is very important, and new teams with limited resources should be able to buy something to take that of the list but I think it’s wrong to be able to buy a swerve, I am totally okay with teams buying a tank or mecanum drive but if you want a swerve you should build it yourself. I mean the goal of First is to make innovation and not that everyone buy’s the same stuff.

posts.name: Andrew Lawrence
posts.cooked: I’ve only personally used the X2i’s, and so far we love them! Assembly was easy, the module does everything we want, and it looks great too. I’m sure the X2S is also great, we just haven’t used them yet.

posts.name: Andrew Todd
posts.cooked: And you can be competitive without it. Your other mechs need to be on-point, but definitely possible.

posts.name: Esat
posts.cooked: x2st is new model for x2i?

posts.name: Liam
posts.cooked:
From what I’ve seen the SDS and WCP are the high end, high quality modules. The Rev is on the lower end of quality from the reports that I’ve seen, and thrifty is somewhere in between.

Personally, I’d push most teams towards the higher end, as the jump in price isn’t huge, but a drive train isn’t where you want a lack of quality…

posts.name: Andrew Lawrence
posts.cooked: Both came out new this year.

posts.name: Esat
posts.cooked: thank you bro, i think wcp is good x2i or x2s we are buying this season

posts.name: Andrew Lawrence
posts.cooked: @R.C 15% commission
